authors.name: Frederick Sanger
authors.description: Two-time Nobel laureate who developed the first methods for DNA sequencing, foundational to genomics.

authors.name: Alec Jeffreys
authors.description: Inventor of DNA fingerprinting and DNA profiling techniques.

authors.name: Svante Pääbo
authors.description: Nobel laureate who pioneered the field of paleogenomics, sequencing the Neanderthal genome.

authors.name: Eric Lander
authors.description: A principal leader of the Human Genome Project and a key figure in genomics.

authors.name: Francis Collins
authors.description: Led the Human Genome Project and served as the Director of the NIH.

authors.name: J. Craig Venter
authors.description: Pioneered shotgun sequencing, which accelerated the Human Genome Project.

authors.name: Mary-Claire King
authors.description: Discovered the BRCA1 gene, linking genetics to hereditary breast cancer.

authors.name: George Church
authors.description: A pioneer in personal genomics, genome engineering, and synthetic biology.

authors.name: Kary Mullis
authors.description: Nobel laureate for inventing the polymerase chain reaction (PCR), a cornerstone of molecular biology.

authors.name: Andrew Z. Fire
authors.description: Nobel laureate for the co-discovery of RNA interference (RNAi).

authors.name: Craig C. Mello
authors.description: Shared the Nobel Prize for the co-discovery of RNA interference (RNAi).

authors.name: David Botstein
authors.description: Helped develop methods for human genetic mapping using RFLPs, a precursor to modern genomics.

authors.name: Jennifer Doudna
authors.description: Nobel laureate and co-inventor of CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technology.

authors.name: Emmanuelle Charpentier
authors.description: Nobel laureate who co-developed the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing tool.

authors.name: Feng Zhang
authors.description: Pioneered the use of CRISPR-Cas9 for genome editing in eukaryotic cells.

authors.name: David Liu
authors.description: Inventor of base editing and prime editing, high-precision next-generation gene editing technologies.

authors.name: Bert Vogelstein
authors.description: Pioneered the genetic model of colorectal cancer, outlining sequential mutations.

authors.name: Robert Weinberg
authors.description: Discovered the first human oncogene (Ras) and co-authored the seminal paper "The Hallmarks of Cancer".

authors.name: Judah Folkman
authors.description: Father of angiogenesis research, proposing that tumors require a blood supply to grow.

authors.name: Tony Hunter
authors.description: Discovered tyrosine phosphorylation, a key mechanism in cell growth and cancer.

authors.name: Dennis Slamon
authors.description: His research led to the development of Herceptin, a targeted therapy for breast cancer.

authors.name: Charles L. Sawyers
authors.description: Instrumental in developing targeted cancer drugs like Gleevec for CML.

authors.name: Napoleone Ferrara
authors.description: His work on VEGF led to the development of anti-angiogenic therapies for cancer and eye disease.

authors.name: James P. Allison
authors.description: Nobel laureate for discovering immune checkpoint therapy, a revolutionary cancer treatment.

authors.name: Tasuku Honjo
authors.description: Nobel laureate for identifying the PD-1 protein, leading to new cancer immunotherapies.

authors.name: Anthony Fauci
authors.description: A leading figure in infectious disease research, particularly HIV/AIDS and COVID-19.

authors.name: Katalin Karikó
authors.description: Nobel laureate whose research on mRNA modifications was foundational for COVID-19 vaccines.

authors.name: Drew Weissman
authors.description: Nobel laureate who, with Katalin Karikó, developed modified mRNA technology for vaccines.

authors.name: Carl June
authors.description: A pioneer of CAR-T cell therapy, a revolutionary form of cancer immunotherapy.

authors.name: Shizuo Akira
authors.description: Made seminal discoveries in innate immunity, particularly regarding Toll-like receptors (TLRs).

authors.name: Yasmine Belkaid
authors.description: Known for her research on the complex interaction between the microbiome and the immune system.

authors.name: Eric Kandel
authors.description: Nobel laureate for his research on the physiological basis of memory storage in neurons.

authors.name: Karl Deisseroth
authors.description: A key developer of optogenetics, a technique to control neurons with light.

authors.name: Edvard Moser
authors.description: Nobel laureate for the co-discovery of grid cells, which form the brain's internal positioning system.

authors.name: May-Britt Moser
authors.description: Shared the Nobel Prize for the discovery of grid cells in the brain, crucial for spatial navigation.

authors.name: Huda Zoghbi
authors.description: Known for her work on the genetic basis of neurological disorders, including Rett syndrome.

authors.name: Thomas Südhof
authors.description: Nobel laureate for his work on the machinery regulating vesicle traffic in our cells, crucial for neurotransmission.

authors.name: Stanley Prusiner
authors.description: Nobel laureate for his discovery of prions, a new biological principle of infection.

authors.name: Karl Friston
authors.description: Developed Statistical Parametric Mapping (SPM) for fMRI analysis and the Free Energy Principle.

authors.name: Yoshinori Ohsumi
authors.description: Nobel laureate for his discoveries of mechanisms for autophagy, the cell's recycling process.

authors.name: James W. Black
authors.description: Nobel laureate who invented beta-blockers and H2 receptor antagonists using rational drug design.

authors.name: Tu Youyou
authors.description: Nobel laureate for discovering Artemisinin, a key drug for treating malaria.

authors.name: Frances Arnold
authors.description: Nobel laureate for pioneering the use of directed evolution to engineer enzymes.

authors.name: Raphael Mechoulam
authors.description: Often called the 'father of cannabis research' for isolating THC and elucidating the endocannabinoid system.

authors.name: Paul Berg
authors.description: Nobel laureate for his fundamental studies of the biochemistry of nucleic acids, particularly recombinant DNA.

authors.name: Gertrude B. Elion
authors.description: Nobel laureate who developed numerous new drugs, using innovative methods of rational drug design.

authors.name: Salim Yusuf
authors.description: Cardiologist who has led some of the largest and most influential global clinical trials.

authors.name: Eugene Braunwald
authors.description: A towering figure in cardiology, often called the "father of modern cardiology" for his extensive contributions.

authors.name: Sir Richard Peto
authors.description: An epidemiologist whose large-scale studies established the risks of tobacco and benefits of statins.

authors.name: Walter Willett
authors.description: A leading researcher in nutrition and epidemiology, known for his work on the Nurses' Health Study.

authors.name: Sir Michael Marmot
authors.description: Pioneered research on health inequalities and the social determinants of health.

authors.name: Paul Farmer
authors.description: A physician and anthropologist who co-founded Partners In Health to provide healthcare in resource-poor settings.

authors.name: Robert Langer
authors.description: An extremely prolific bioengineer, a pioneer of drug delivery systems and tissue engineering.

authors.name: Shinya Yamanaka
authors.description: Nobel laureate for discovering how to reprogram adult cells into induced pluripotent stem cells (iPS cells).

authors.name: James A. Thomson
authors.description: Derived the first human embryonic stem cell line in 1998.

authors.name: César Milstein
authors.description: Nobel laureate who, with Georges Köhler, developed the hybridoma technique for monoclonal antibodies.

authors.name: Ian Wilmut
authors.description: Led the team that performed the first cloning of a mammal from an adult cell, Dolly the sheep.

authors.name: Robert Edwards
authors.description: Nobel laureate for the development of in vitro fertilization (IVF).

authors.name: David Haussler
authors.description: Led the team that assembled the first public draft of the human genome sequence and pioneered computational genomics.

authors.name: Michael S. Waterman
authors.description: Co-developer of the Smith-Waterman algorithm, a cornerstone of biological sequence alignment.

authors.name: Janet Thornton
authors.description: A leader in structural bioinformatics, focusing on protein structure, function, and evolution.

authors.name: Peer Bork
authors.description: A pioneer in the analysis of metagenomes, particularly the human microbiome, and computational systems biology.

authors.name: Aviv Regev
authors.description: A key figure in the development of single-cell genomics and its application to understand cellular circuits.

authors.name: Demis Hassabis
authors.description: Co-founder of DeepMind and a leader behind AlphaFold, which revolutionized protein structure prediction.

authors.name: John Jumper
authors.description: Led the development of the AlphaFold algorithm at DeepMind.

authors.name: Ewan Birney
authors.description: Co-director of EMBL-EBI and a key figure in major bioinformatics projects like ENCODE and the Human Genome Project.
